_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Visual inspection of chlorine vaporizer system

_exec_summary.SummaryText: ity has not had incident releases of chlorine in the past five years.  Any release inside the storage building is neutralized by the dry scrubber.  The emergency response program:  The facility does not have a HazMat Team in place to offensively respond to releases of chlorine.  The plant has coordinated emergency response procedures with the Wabash County Emergency Management Agency and conducted a mock disaster exercise in May of 2016 that involved several response agencies responding to a chlorine incident.  In the event of a release which could result in an offsite impact, the Emergency Management Agency will be contacted to alert the general public.  The facility has constructed a building for storage and distribution of chlorine (2011).  A dry scrubber and ventilation system has been installed with the building to capture and control potential releases from inside the building.  Sensors/monitors for chlorine have been installed in the building that activate the scrubber system. Video surveillance of the chlorine storage building has been installed in addition to plant entrances.  Planned changes to improve safety: The facility will continue to make improvements as identified through employee participation and internal auditing programs.  A recent improvement was to install a display outside of the storage building that shows the ppm inside of the building.  The projects planned for completion in 2023 include replacement of piping and system controls throughout the facility.

The accidental release and emergency response policies at the facility:  Real Alloy Specification LLC is committed to maintaining a safe work environment for our employees, contractors, visitors and the surrounding public.  Representatives from the facility are actively involved in meetings with outside responders, such as the Local Emergency Planning Committee in order to establish emergency response procedures necessary to protect the surrounding public and environment.  The facility and the regulated substances handled:  The Real Alloy facility produces recycled secondary specification aluminum alloys.  The facility has a Program 3 covered process due to onsite storage and use of chlorine.  Chlorine is used to remove magnesium and impurities from molten aluminum.  The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  The facility is covered by EPA's Risk Management Program rule and OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule for the process using chlorine.  The facility implements one combined Process Safety and Risk Management Program.  This program consists of a written management system that complies with both USEPA's and OSHA's requirements. The Management of Change procedure enables the facility to initiate and complete process changes associated with the chlorine system.  A project to make significant system improvements is expected to started in late 2022 and be completed by mid-2023.  The worst case scenario is based upon a failure of a chlorine cylinder during delivery to the facility.  The alternative release scenarios were modeled based on equipment failure between the vaporizer and the furnace where the gas is injected into the molten metal bath. The mechanical integrity element of the program is key in preventing releases.  The facility utilizes a computerized maintenance management system (MVP) to implement preventive maintenance, testing and inspection of the chlorine system.
